DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnPrint: cnt = cnt + 1 if cnt mod 2 = 0 then detail.backcolor = rgb(200,220,200) else detail.backcolor = rgb(255,255,255) endif

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report uses the OnPrint event of the detail section to alternate the BackColor property of the section.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report sets the Layout.CustomWidth and Layout.CustomHeight properties to create a custom paper size (8.5 x 25"). When specified this way, the custom paper size is used regardless of what printers are installed and what paper sizes are actually available.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report has a field bound to a static image file. The image file can be embedded in the report definition at design time, or it can be a reference to an external file. Use the View|Options menu in the designer to select the option you prefer (check Embed Images).

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report has a field bound to images stored in the database. The field's Picture property is set to the string "Photo", which is the name of a binary field that contains employee photos stored as embedded OLE bitmaps. Images stores as raw byte streams would also work.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.CategoryName, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report uses the Layout.Picture property to display an image as a watermark. The watermark is displayed behind the report content. You can control the way the watermark is scaled and the pages on which it should appear using the Layout.PictureAlign and Layout.PictureShow properties.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report has several fields in its detail section. All fields have the CanGrow and CanShrink properties set to true. Notice how the Name and Address fields grow and push down the Notes field. The Notes field in turn grows and pushes down the blue Country fields. It does not push down the red Country field because it is not directly above it.

Field.Name: Field12
Field.Text: This will grow because it's Anchored:

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.CategoryName, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnPrint:
cnt = cnt + 1 detail.forcepagebreak = "none"
if cnt >= 10 then cnt = 0 detail.forcepagebreak = "after" endif

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report uses the OnPrint event of the detail section to count how many detail lines have been printed on the current page. When that number equals 10, the script uses the section's ForcePageBreak property to cause a page break.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.CategoryName, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnPrint:
cnt = cnt + 1 detail.forcepagebreak = "none"
if cnt >= linesPerPage then cnt = 0 detail.forcepagebreak = "after" endif

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report creates page breaks after a given number of detail lines have been rendered. The number of detail lines per page is defined by the value of an invisible field called "linesPerPage". A caller application can change the value of the field before renderign the report, thereby changing the number of lines per page in the report.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.CategoryName, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Section.Name: PageHeader
Section.OnFormat: odd = (page mod 2 <> 0) h1odd.Visible = odd h2odd.Visible = odd h1even.Visible = not odd h2even.Visible = not odd

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report changes the page header section based on the current page number. This is done with some script attached to the page header's OnFormat event. The script changes the visibility of some fields based on whether the page number is odd or even. The report also suppresses the page header on the first page by setting the Layout.PageHeader property to NotWithReportHdr.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.CategoryName, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report changes the Layout.MarginLeft property based on the current page number. This creates a "gutter", where odd pages have a larger margin in order to facilitate binding.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.CategoryName, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: Adding charts to reports is easy. All you have to do is add a Chart field to a group header section and set the Chart's DataX and DataY properties to the values you want to display on the chart. You can show several series by setting the DataY property to a list of fields delimited by semicolons (e.g. "UnitsInStock;ReorderLevel"). The Chart data is automatically scoped to the current report group, so when rendering the "Beverages" section, only data for that category will be charted. You can customize the chart using the ChartType, GridLines, Use3D, and Palette properties.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.*, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text:
You can create your own custom fields and add them to the report designer palette. To do that, you have to:
1) Create a custom field class that derives from C1.Win.C1Report.Field. 2) Register your custom field assembly in the report designer's settings file.
This is how the Chart and Gradient fields are implemented. The source code for these custom fields is available, you can use it as a starting point to create your own custom fields.
The Chart and Gradient fields are registered in the settings file with this entry:

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Orders.ShipName, dbo.Orders.OrderDate, Sum(dbo.[Order Details].UnitPrice * dbo.[Order Details].Quantity) AS OrderValue FROM (dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID) INNER JOIN (dbo.Orders INNER JOIN dbo.[Order Details] ON dbo.Orders.OrderID = dbo.[Order Details].OrderID) ON dbo.Products.ProductID = dbo.[Order Details].ProductID GROUP BY dbo.Orders.ShipName, dbo.Orders.OrderDate ORDER BY dbo.Orders.ShipName, dbo.Orders.OrderDate;

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report uses the Sum and Avg aggregate functions to calculate total and average order amounts. The aggregate functions are used in expressions assigned to the Text property of the report fields. The scope of the aggregate functions is determined by their position in the report. Aggregates in group headers or footers have the scope of the group. Aggregates in the report header or footer have the scope of the entire report. You can reduce the scope of any aggregate using a second argument called 'domain'. For example, Count(*, OrderValue > 1000) returns the number of orders over $1000.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: * NOTE: Items listed in red need to be ordered immediately.

Field.Name: Field3
Field.Text: Page Header and Page Footer sections in subreports are not rendered. Instead, the Page Header and Page Footer sections of the main report are used. If you want your subreports to have sections that repeat across page breaks, add a group to the subreport and place the fields to be repeated in the group's header section. Remember to set the Repeat property of the header section to true so it will repeat on every page break.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnFormat: UnitsInStockCtl.ForeColor = _ iif( UnitsInStock + UnitsOnOrder > ReorderLevel, _ rgb(0,0,0), _ rgb(255,0,0))

Section.Name: New Group Header
Section.OnPrint:
' calculate a value and store it in the report's Tag property Report.Tag = Avg(UnitPrice)
' store some other values in invisible fields fMinPrice = Min(UnitPrice) fMaxPrice = Max(UnitPrice) fAvgPrice = Avg(UnitPrice)

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: * NOTE: This section will not be rendered if this is used as a subreport.

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: The headers on this report are placed in a group header section, and its Repeat property is set to true. This causes the headers to repeat at the top of evey page, just as if they were page headers. This technique is useful in subreports, since the page header and page footer sections of subreports are never rendered (the ones in the main report are rendered instead).

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: * NOTE: Items listed in red need to be ordered immediately.

Field.Name: Field3
Field.Text: In some cases you may want to pass data from the subreport back to the main report. Script variables can't be used for this because each report has its own script scope (this avoids the possibility of conflicting variable names). To pass data from a subreport back to the main report, you have to store values in the subreport fields or in the Tag property, then have the main report read those values. In this sample, the subreport calculates the average unit price per product category and stores that value in its Tag property and also in some invisible fields. The main report retrieves and displays those values.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnFormat: If UnitsInStock + UnitsOnOrder < ReorderLevel And Discontinued = False Then Detail.BackColor = rgb(255,190,190) Else Detail.BackColor = vbWhite Endif

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: * NOTE: Items listed in red need to be ordered immediately.

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report lists all products in stock and highlights those that need to be ordered immediately. This is done with a script attached to the detail section's OnFormat event. The script changes the detail section's BackColor depending on the value of the fields UnitsInStock, UnitsOnOrder, ReorderLevel, and Discontinued.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: Format(Page, "Total stock listed on page 0 is: ") & Format(pageSum, "#,##0")

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: The Field object has a RunningSum property that makes is easy to maintain running sums over groups or over the entire report. To keep running sums over pages, you need to use script. This report uses a field called "pageSum" which is updated in the OnPage and OnPrint events.

Report.Name: 18: Continued Headers

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Categories.*, dbo.Products.* FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN dbo.Products ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID;

Report.OnOpen: ' calculate a value and store it in the report's Tag property Report.Tag = Avg(UnitPrice)

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnFormat: UnitsInStockCtl.ForeColor = _ iif( UnitsInStock + UnitsOnOrder > ReorderLevel, _ rgb(0,0,0), _ rgb(255,0,0))

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: * NOTE: Items listed in red need to be ordered immediately.

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: Group header sections are repeated across page breaks if their "Repeat" property is set to true. This report uses some script to add a "Continued" label next to group headers that were added because of such page breaks. The report uses a field called "fContinued" that is initially invisible. The detail section OnPrint event makes "fContinued" visible, and the group footer makes it invisible again. If a page break occurs in the middle of a group, the field is displayed in the group header section.

Report.Name: 19: Sorting

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Report.OnOpen: Report.Groups(0).GroupBy = Replace([Sort Report By], " ", "") Report.Groups(0).Sort = [Sort Direction]

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: There are two ways to sort data in reports: you can sort the data source object (e.g. using an ORDER BY clause in your Sql statement), or you can add groups to the report and specify how each group should be sorted using the group's "GroupBy" and "Sort" properties. This report uses a parameterized query and allows you to select the field you want to sort on and the sort direction.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: SELECT dbo.Orders.ShipCountry, dbo.Categories.CategoryName, Year([OrderDate]) AS OrderYear, Sum(dbo.[Order Details].[UnitPrice] * dbo.[Order Details].[Quantity]-[Discount]) AS SaleAmount, DatePart("q",[OrderDate]) AS OrderQtr FROM dbo.Categories INNER JOIN (dbo.Products INNER JOIN (dbo.Orders INNER JOIN dbo.[Order Details] ON dbo.Orders.OrderID = dbo.[Order Details].OrderID) ON dbo.Products.ProductID = dbo.[Order Details].ProductID) ON dbo.Categories.CategoryID = dbo.Products.CategoryID GROUP BY dbo.Orders.ShipCountry, dbo.Categories.CategoryName, Year([OrderDate]), DatePart("q",[OrderDate]) ORDER BY dbo.Orders.ShipCountry, dbo.Categories.CategoryName, Year([OrderDate]);

Field.Name: Field4
Field.Text:
Cross-tab reports group data in two dimensions (down and across). They are useful for summarizing large amounts of data in a format that cross-references information.
To create cross-tab reports, you will typically start with a GROUP BY query to summarize the data into rows, then use a transformation service to create the grouped columns. The transformation service can be provided by the database server itself, it can be a custom program, or you can use C1Report's built-in domain aggregates.
This report uses the latter approach. The data source has an "OrderQtr" field that contains the quarter when the orders were placed. The report's group header has expressions of the form "sum(SaleAmount, OrderQtr = 1)". These expressions add up all the sales for the corresponding quarter. The report produces the cross-tab view placing four of these expressions side-by-side.
Note that the detail section in this report is hidden. If you make it visible you will see what the underlying data looks like.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: To suppress the display of fields with value zero, set their Format property to "#". The pound sign is a formatting symbol that displays only significant digits (no leading or trailing zeros). To force the display of a certain number of digits, use a format like "0000". The zero forces the display of a digit, including leading and trailing zeros.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Section.Name: Detail
Section.OnFormat: UnitsInStockCtl.ForeColor = _ iif( UnitsInStock + UnitsOnOrder > ReorderLevel, _ rgb(0,0,0), _ rgb(255,0,0))

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: * NOTE: This section will not be rendered if this is used as a subreport.

Field.Name: Field
Field.Text: This report uses the LinkTarget property to implement a Print button. When the report is exported to Html, and viewed in a browser, clicking the button runs a short script (window.print()) that allows the user to print the report.

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""

Field.Name: Field1
Field.Text: This report has a single calculated field that builds a letter for each 'customer' (actually the products).

Field.Name: Field2
Field.Text: "Hello " + ProductName + "," + vbcrlf + vbcrlf + _ "Your account balance is " + Format(UnitPrice, "Currency") + vbcrlf + vbcrlf + _ "Because you have been such a terrific customer, " + _ "we decided to credit your account with $0.10." + vbcrlf + vbcrlf + _ "Your new account balance will be " + vbcrlf + _ Format(fldBalance + 0.10, "Currency") + vbcrlf + vbcrlf + _ "Congratulations!"

DataSource.ConnectionString: Provider=SQLNCLI10.1;User ID=joe;Password=user;Initial Catalog=C1NWindSQL;Data Source=CORSIE\SQLEXPRESS;Initial File Name="";Server SPN=""
DataSource.RecordSource: PARAMETERS [Beginning Date] DateTime 1/1/1994, [Ending Date] DateTime 1/1/1995, [Sales Goal] Int 15000; SELECT DISTINCT dbo.Employees.Country, dbo.Employees.LastName, dbo.Employees.FirstName, dbo.Orders.ShippedDate, dbo.Orders.OrderID, dbo.[Order Subtotals].Subtotal AS SaleAmount FROM dbo.Employees INNER JOIN (dbo.Orders INNER JOIN dbo.[Order Subtotals] ON dbo.Orders.OrderID = dbo.[Order Subtotals].OrderID) ON dbo.Employees.EmployeeID = dbo.Orders.EmployeeID WHERE (((dbo.Orders.ShippedDate) Between [Beginning Date] And [Ending Date]));

Section.Name: LastName_Header
Section.OnFormat: If SalespersonTotal > [Sales Goal] Then ExceededGoalLabel.Visible = True SalespersonLine.Visible = True Else ExceededGoalLabel.Visible = False SalespersonLine.Visible = False End If

Field.Name: Field2
Field.Text:
This report shows how to include page numbers and counts for grouped reports.
C1Report always had two report variables for the current and total number of pages in the report (Page and Pages).
In Version 196, we added two script functions that return the current and total number of pages for the current group. The functions are called GroupPage(g) and GroupPages(g). The "g" parameter specifies which group to use, and can be either an index or the group name.
In the report below, the drag blue fields contain expressions like "Page " & GroupPage(0) & " of " & GroupPages(0)
These expressions show the current page within the first group (index zero) and the total number of pages for each instance of the first group (in this example, there are two instances of the first group: UK and USA).
